entry.title: Master Data Management via Business Data Cloud: Datasphere & Seamless Planning in combination
entry.content:
SAP Datasphere and SAC Seamless Planning will play an increasingly important role in the future. Since Seamless Planning is still a relatively young product, its current interaction capabilities with SAP Datasphere are limited. Nevertheless, this example demonstrates how master data from SAP Datasphere can already be enriched and managed using Seamless Planning.

Setup SAP Datasphere

Let us assume that we have two tables in SAP Datasphere:

  • Customer Table
    • CustomerNumber
    • CustomerName
    • Country
    • RegionCode
  • Region Table
    • RegionCode
    • Description

Our goal is to assign regions to customers via Seamless Planning and maintain the description of the regions.

To achieve this, we create local tables for both dimensions and expose them through fact view and analytical model for SAC consumption. (For the fact view, we simply added a row counter as a key figure.)

  1. Customer Table
  2. Customer Fact View
  3. Customer Analytical Model

SAC Data Preview:

And like this for the Region Model

  1. Region Table
  2. Region Fact View
  3. Region Analytical Model

SAC Data Preview:

Setup SAP Analytics Cloud

In SAC we also create two dimensions, one for Customer Region Assignment and one for the Region. We then expose both to SAP Datasphere.

The dimension for the Customer Region Assignment looks like this in SAC:

It also has a property with region:

The Dimension for Region looks like this:

We then also create a Dummy Planning Model which will hold our dimension and Dummy Keyfigure as it is required. This one is also exposed to SAP Datasphere.

Setup Planning Application in SAP Analytics Cloud

We then build a story in SAC, including:

  • The two analytical models (Customer and Region)
  • The dummy planning model

Tables with the data can be displayed (or hidden in a real application).

Customer Region Assignment

In the Customer Region Assignment tab, we add two dropdowns, one for the Customer Selection and one for the Region it should be assigned. On the initialization we fill the dropdowns with the following script:

var customers = Customer.getDataSource().getMembers("CustomerNumber");
var customerName = Customer.getDataSource().getMembers("CustomerName");

console.log(customers);

for (var i = 0; i<customers.length;i++){
	CustomerDropdown.addItem(customers[i].displayId, customerName[i].displayId);
	
}

var regions = Region.getDataSource().getMembers("RegionCode");
console.log(regions);


for (var j = 0; j<regions.length;j++){
	RegionDropdown.addItem(regions[j].displayId);
	
}

This way the dropdown gets filled with our Data from the Analytical Models and the dimension values from SAP Datasphere.

An Assignment could then be done by selecting the Customer and the Region.

When the Save button is pressed the script performs the following actions and updates the dimension:

var region = RegionDropdown.getSelectedKey();
var customer = CustomerDropdown.getSelectedKey();
var customerText = CustomerDropdown.getSelectedText();

console.log(region);
console.log(customer);

CustomerInput=({id:customer, description:customerText ,properties:{Region:region}});
console.log(CustomerInput);

DummyModel.updateMembers("CustomerRegionAssignment",CustomerInput);

As the dimension is stored in Datasphere we can now see the values in the Seamless planning table.

We now add this table in a Transformation flow as Source and add this information to our original Datasphere table which holds the Customer Information.

Region Text Maintenance

In this tab we do something very similar. We add one Dropdown to select for which region you want to maintain the text and one text input to maintain it. The dropdown is again filled upon initialization of the page with the following script:

var regions = RegionText.getDataSource().getMembers("RegionCode");
var regionsText = RegionText.getDataSource().getMembers("Description");

for (var j = 0; j<regions.length;j++){
	RegionTextDropdown.addItem(regions[j].displayId, regionsText[j].displayId);
	
}

And that based on the selection the text input is filled:

var sel = RegionTextDropdown.getSelectedText();
console.log(sel);

RegionTextMaint.setValue(sel);

In the application this looks like:

Upon the Button execution the dimension is updated:

var region = RegionTextDropdown.getSelectedKey();
var regionText = RegionTextMaint.getValue();

console.log(region);
console.log(regionText);

RegionTextInput=({id:region, description:regionText});
console.log(CustomerInput);

DummyModel.updateMembers("Region",RegionTextInput);

Identical to the example above the value is then stored in SAP Datasphere and a Transformation Flow writes the value into its original table:

Conclusion and Outlook

In practice, transformation flows could be triggered through a task chain, initiated by a multi-action in SAC. This will become easier once SAP provides an API to trigger task chains, or by using our solution to wrap the task chain CLI (Link ZPARTNER; Link SAP Community).

Looking ahead, the goal is for transformation flows to become unnecessary‚Äîenabling direct master data management in Seamless Planning, similar to the functionality available in SAP BW/4HANA.

Even though Seamless Planning is still a young functionality, with some creativity and ideation, it already offers ways to enrich SAP Datasphere data and design new planning processes using SAP‚Äôs latest cloud technology stack.

entry.title: Easier Integration of SAP CIS with BDC (SAC, DSP, BDCC) with a new Identity Provider Administration
entry.content:
Overview

SAP Cloud Identity Services (CIS) are a group of services which enable you to integrate identity and access management between systems. The goal is to provide a seamless single sign-on experience across systems while ensuring that system and data access are secure.

CIS provides several out-of-the-box features that your BDC Components and Non-BDC SAC/Datasphere do not have. 

The new IDP Admin tool will be turned on sometime in Q3. We will have a phased deployment strategy on different landscapes.

 

Why should we integrate with IAS?

Integration with SAP CIS will solve many of the identity challenges facing BDC and Non-BDC tenants. Over the years, we've had a number of influence requests asking for features related to identity in SAC and Datasphere. With a deeper integration with CIS, we can tackle many of those influence requests.

Here are just some of the benefits you will receive with integration with CIS: 

  • Conditional Authentication allows you to create users to authenticate into SAC/DSP without needing to create the user in your corporate identity provider
  • Moves the Groups=sac requirement onto IAS, instead of your corporate IDP
  • Supports multiple corporate Identity Providers
  • Single IAS can be used for SuccessFactors and then BDC
  • Improved Monitoring and Auditing
  • Improved Security in which you can use SAML or OpenID Connect
  • Future proofing as most enhancements to authentication will be made to IAS

To make it easier to "bundle" with CIS, we have updated our Identity Provisioning Administration Tool (IDP-Admin). 

In this blog, I'll show you how to do this step by step

Controlled Release

We are enabling the new IDP Admin tool in a controlled release. More details are here:

PhasesLandscapesDateBDC Products ImpactedStatus
Phase 1JP30, BR30, SA31Week of Sept 8th 2025SAC, DSPComplete
Phase 2AP30, BR20, IL30, SA30, US21, CH20Week of Sept 22nd 2025SAC, DSPComplete
Phase 3US30, AP12, CA10, IN30, EU11, AP11, EU30Week of Oct 13th 2025SAC, DSPNot started
Phase 4BR10, JP10, AP10, US20, US10, EU20, EU10Week of Nov 3rd 2025SAC, DSP, BDCNot Started
     

Getting Started

  • Persona: Administrator - You are the System Owner of tenant (SAC, DSP or BDCC)
  • Terminology: When referring to BDC Components or BDC, we are referring to SAP Analytics Cloud, Datasphere and Databricks. Although our example is coming out of SAP Analytics Cloud.  
  • The bundling tool is also available for Non-BDC SAC and Datasphere. In general, you may see this grouped in with BDC as the workflows are the same. 

How to do it?

In the below example, I'll cover the most common scenario our customers are dealing with. Your SAC or Datasphere is currently configured with your Corporate IDP directly.  

CIS Integration with your Corporate Identity Provider

In tenants where you are already using your corporate IDP with SAC/DSP/BDCC or you intend on using your corporate IDP, follow these steps. 

 

  1. Go to System > Administration > Security and scroll down to click on Launch Identity Provider Administration Tool
  2. Logon to Identity Provider Administration Tool (IDP Admin) using the System Owner user. If you don't have an account, click Register to create a new account. 
  3. Once logged in, you will see a tile representing the BDC Component (either SAC, DSP or BDCC).

    In our example, we have an SAC system. 

     


    From the context menu, Repair IdP will allow you to revert back to the default IDP or update the IDP metadata.


    For bundling, please select Add SAP Cloud Identity Services
    ** Note down the Tenant Type as this will be important in a few steps **

  4. The next screen will show you a list of all CIS tenants that you have deployed. You are entitled to Production and Test CIS tenants. If an IAS tenant is already used by another tenant like SuccessFactors or Ariba, this will appear on the list.  In addition, if you have purchased an IAS separately, it will also appear on this list. 



    As a best practice, it is recommended you select the IAS tenant that matches your tenant type from the Tile (in Step 3) 

    If you do not have any CIS provisioned yet, the Provision New SAP Cloud Identity Services Tenant button is enabled. This will provision a IAS which you can then bundle to.

  5. Input the System Owner details

  6. The last step is a summary of actions. 



    Click Finish
  7. CIS will be provisioned with your current tenant. This step does NOT change over the authentication source quite yet.




    Success!

    Clicking Continue will bring you to the final set up stage which is to validate and turn on authentication. In our case, since we are planning on integration our corporate IDP solution, we will click Close. 

  8. Log into CIS and go to Applications & Resources > Applications. You will see a new entry representing the BDC tenant that was just bundled.

    ** Note although the application has been created and some pre-configuration has been done, the authentication has not switched over to IAS yet. **

  9. The next step is an important step because we are going to use the same corporate IdP as before. To do this, follow these steps here: https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-identity-services/cloud-identity-services/create-corporate-idp-in-administration-console?version=Cloud 

  10. Ensure that the Application's default authenticating Identity Provider is set to the corporate identity provider
  11. Check the Corporate Identity Providers in IAS to make sure "Use Identity Authentication user store" is enabled. This will make sure that the assertions contain the data needed by SAC/DSP/BDCC
  12. Now that you have configured your corporate IdP, it's time to finish the configuration and switch over the authentication.
    Go back to IDP Admin and then go to the Tile. 

    You can see the tile still says it is pending. Simply click on the
  13. Select an attribute type (default Email), provide the subject name identifier and select dynamic user creation if desired.



    **Note: Dynamic User creation will create new users during the logon time.
    For instance, I send a story to Sarah in SAC. Sarah has never used SAC before. She clicks on the link and she is prompted for her corporate portal login. A SAC user is created for Sarah and her user will now appear in System > Users. Sarah is now able to view the story. 


  14. The next step requires you open a new tab in incognito mode and use the validation URL. Make sure any existing Incognito windows signed into SAC are closed before opening the new one. 



    Log onto the tenant and then you should see:

    Close the tab

  15. Go back to the previous window and select validate login:




  16. Review the settings and then click Finish



     

  17. The following success message should appear: 


     

  18. The tile has now been updated. 
  19. You have now completed the bundling exercise. You can now take advantage of the amazing features that IAS brings. Find all the documentation here: https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-identity-services

 

Quick Q&A

 

Q: I have set up my corporate IDP with IAS, but I want to authenticate into SAC or Datasphere with an alternate user?  How do I do that?

A: We refer to this as Conditional Authentication which can be configured in IAS. Create a rule specifically for a email domain or a group to use the Identity Authentication (local IAS user) instead of the corporate IDP.  More details here 

Q: How do I set up multiple Corporate IDP's?

A: Add a second IDP through IAS > Identity Providers > Corporate Identity Providers. After that, in the IAS application, add conditional authentication to support multiple IDP's based on email domain or groups.

Q: Does having multiple Corporate IDPs impact licensing for SAC?

A: No it should not impact licensing as the license thresholds are based on SAC Users that are created in the system. 

Q: How will a greenfield situation work where a tenant is new and has no users

A: The steps for greenfield will nearly be the same. At a high level, you would still go to IDP Admin and trigger the bundling. After the bundling step is done, you can configure the corporate IDP or just choose to leave it IAS as the main identity provider.

entry.title: Implementing SAP Emarsys Loyalty Management - Part 1
entry.content:
Introduction and Overview

This blog presents an end-to-end architecture for SAP Emarsys Loyalty, bringing together loyalty program design, omnichannel engagement, and closed-loop financial posting to strengthen repeat purchases and customer lifetime value.

It provides a structured view of how the solution is organized‚Äîcovering applications, modules, and data objects and illustrates core processes such as onboarding, plan and tier-based accrual, voucher or points redemption, and service-driven adjustments.

Additionally, it explains how segmentation, personalization tokens, and analytics with Datasphere and SAC will be leveraged to operationalize loyalty programs and measure outcomes across channels.

Architecture

The following reference architecture explains how SAP Emarsys Loyalty can be implemented with other SAP solutions, though it may vary for different customer implementations depending on the systems they use.              Emarsys Loyalty Architecture

Based on this reference architecture, the following SAP solutions are proposed for integration with SAP Emarsys Loyalty.

  • SAP S/4 HANA will handle loyalty points earned through transactions such as sales orders and retail purchases, with real-time posting of point accruals and redemptions to ensure financial accuracy.
  • Web or mobile apps may be used to let customers check their loyalty activity, view offers and exclusive access, and track points, tiers, and plans through a digital wallet.
  • SAP Service Cloud will give customer service agents a complete view of the loyalty profile, including tier, balance, and past redemptions, enabling them to resolve issues like missing points, redemption problems, or upgrades.
  • Campaign channels such as email, mobile, and web will be used to run loyalty campaigns, encourage purchases, share offers, and update customers on their tier or points status.
  • Finally, SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud will provide reports, dashboards, and stories related to loyalty performance.

 

End-to-End Loyalty process flow

Customer Registration and Loyalty on Boarding

Customer registration and loyalty onboarding start with joining the program to enjoy benefits from purchases and activities. New customers can enroll during registration, while existing customers can join anytime. For both, a hash ID must be generated and assigned to their record before they can join. Enrollment can be done through mobile apps, websites, or POS systems.

 

Points accrual

Points accrual allows customers to earn loyalty points and benefits based on their purchases and activities. For purchases, data is sent from SAP ERP to Smart Insight and then to Loyalty, where points and benefits are calculated based on the customer‚Äôs plan and tier. The confirmed points are then sent back to SAP ERP/S4 HANA for financial posting.

 

Points Redemption:

 At checkout, customers can either use an existing voucher they have already claimed or pay directly with their points. When a voucher is claimed, the points are redeemed at that time. If customers pay directly with points, the points are deducted from their balance, and the financial postings are then processed in SAP S/4HANA. 

 

Customer Service Support scenarios for points

Customer service support for points comes into play when customers raise issues such as missing rewards, incorrect deductions, or other loyalty-related queries. A ticket or case is created in the Service Cloud, where an agent can view the customer‚Äôs loyalty profile through an interface. The agent can then adjust points or tiers as needed, and each change triggers the corresponding financial postings in SAP S/4HANA

 

Loyalty Segmentation, Personalization and Campaigns

 Loyalty segmentation, personalization, and campaigns are managed using relational data templates to create customer segments. These segments are then used across different channels to run targeted campaigns. Personalization tokens ensure that campaign messages are customized for each customer before being sent.

 

Loyalty reports and Dashboards

Loyalty data is shared with Google Cloud Platform through open data views. These views can be used to build models within SAP Datasphere, and the models are then consumed in SAP Analytics Cloud for reporting and analysis.

 

Conclusion

This blog lays out an architecture blueprint for SAP Emarsys Loyalty, showing how businesses can run smarter, more connected loyalty programs by combining customer engagement, financial accuracy, and personalized experiences. It supports the complete loyalty lifecycle from enrollment, earning and burning points, to customer service and reporting, while integrating seamlessly with SAP systems such as S/4HANA, Service Cloud, and Analytics Cloud, along with mobile and web apps. This ensures customers enjoy a smooth, rewarding experience across all touchpoints, while businesses strengthen retention, boost revenue, and build lasting brand loyalty.

Stay tuned for upcoming posts where we will share business processes, customizations, and technical insights‚Äîhighlighting how each component comes together to deliver a seamless loyalty experience.

To be continued‚Ä¶

Co-Authors :  @lokeshla (Lokesh Lakhondae) and @vijaysb15 (Vijay SB)

entry.title: üöÄ SAP BTP Weekly: seguridad reforzada, IA aplicada y nuevas alianzas estrat√©gicas
entry.content:
SAP AI Core y modelos propios en BTP Las empresas ya pueden entrenar y desplegar sus propios modelos en SAP AI Core con integraci√≥n nativa a datos SAP. Esto abre la puerta a IA especializada en cada industria, pero plantea un dilema: ¬øc√≥mo equilibrar innovaci√≥n con compliance? Una aseguradora podr√≠a entrenar un modelo para detecci√≥n de fraudes, pero ¬øqu√© pasa si no logra explicabilidad suficiente? La promesa es grande, el riesgo tambi√©n.

¬øTu organizaci√≥n est√° lista para invertir en IA propia o prefer√≠s modelos preentrenados de SAP y partners?

üîó M√°s informaci√≥n

Nuevo release de SAP Integration Suite La suite incorpora conectores preconfigurados para Salesforce, Workday y ServiceNow, simplificando arquitecturas h√≠bridas. El beneficio es velocidad en despliegues, pero la realidad es que muchas empresas ya tienen middleware paralelo. Un retail puede ver valor en unificar todo en BTP, pero el costo de ‚Äúmigrar lo viejo‚Äù nunca es trivial.

¬øVale la pena consolidar integraciones en una sola plataforma o es mejor convivir con m√∫ltiples soluciones?

üîó M√°s informaci√≥n

DataSphere y federaci√≥n en tiempo real SAP Datasphere suma capacidades para federar datos en vivo desde Snowflake y BigQuery, sin replicaci√≥n masiva. Esto cambia el juego: menos ETL, m√°s velocidad. Una minera podr√≠a consultar KPIs financieros y de producci√≥n en un √∫nico dashboard, pero la latencia y la calidad de metadatos pueden ser tal√≥n de Aquiles.

¬øCre√©s que el futuro es federar datos en vivo o seguir apostando a replicar en un √∫nico repositorio?

üîó M√°s informaci√≥n

Joule for Developers: IA gratis hasta 2026 El programa permite a los desarrolladores usar capacidades de IA generativa dentro de SAP Build Code, Build Apps, Process Automation y entornos ABAP sin costo hasta septiembre de 2026. Esto acelera la creaci√≥n de aplicaciones, automatiza procesos y mejora la productividad, pero tambi√©n plantea un reto: ¬øc√≥mo asegurar que los equipos realmente adopten la herramienta y no quede como ‚Äúdemo eterna‚Äù? Imaginemos un equipo de manufactura que genera c√≥digo para integrarse con sensores IoT en minutos, pero sin estrategia de adopci√≥n puede terminar en pilotos aislados sin impacto real.

¬øEn tu empresa ya est√°n explorando Joule for Developers o a√∫n se percibe como una prueba de laboratorio sin plan de escalamiento?

üîó M√°s informaci√≥n

Gesti√≥n de identidades con CIS: m√°s all√° del SSO SAP Cloud Identity Services ya no es solo un proveedor de inicio de sesi√≥n √∫nico: hoy permite aplicar MFA (autenticaci√≥n multifactor), gestionar identidades externas y controlar accesos en entornos h√≠bridos. El beneficio es claro: menos riesgos de seguridad y m√°s trazabilidad. Pero el desaf√≠o aparece en la pr√°ctica: ¬øqui√©n define los roles y qui√©n se hace responsable de revisarlos peri√≥dicamente? Una empresa de energ√≠a implement√≥ MFA para usuarios cr√≠ticos, pero descubri√≥ que sin procesos de recertificaci√≥n, la complejidad administrativa creci√≥ exponencialmente.

¬øEn tu organizaci√≥n la gesti√≥n de identidades es una pr√°ctica madura con roles y procesos claros, o sigue siendo una tarea reactiva que depende del equipo Basis?

üîó M√°s informaci√≥n

Sustainability Control Tower: visibilidad ESG en tiempo real La herramienta permite consolidar m√©tricas ambientales, sociales y de gobernanza en un solo panel conectado a SAP y fuentes externas. El valor es dar a CFOs y responsables de sostenibilidad una visi√≥n clara para reportes y decisiones estrat√©gicas. Integrada con BTP, gana a√∫n m√°s potencia: puede aprovechar conectores preconfigurados, flujos de datos en tiempo real y dashboards de anal√≠tica avanzada, evitando desarrollos ad-hoc y reduciendo el time-to-value. El reto est√° en la calidad y consistencia de los datos: una empresa de retail logr√≥ integrar emisiones de su cadena log√≠stica, pero descubri√≥ que sin estandarizar la captura de datos de proveedores, los reportes perd√≠an comparabilidad.

¬øTu empresa ya mide indicadores ESG de forma integrada con SAP o todav√≠a depende de reportes manuales y dispersos?

üîó M√°s informaci√≥n

SAP Build Apps y citizen developers El nuevo release permite que usuarios de negocio creen apps m√≥viles con integraci√≥n directa a SAP S/4HANA. Esto democratiza la innovaci√≥n, pero el riesgo es el shadow IT. Un equipo de log√≠stica puede crear su propia app de seguimiento, pero ¬øqu√© pasa si no pasa controles de seguridad? El rol de IT pasa de desarrollador a ‚Äúcurador‚Äù.

¬øEn tu empresa los citizen developers son aliados estrat√©gicos o una fuente de dolores de cabeza?

üîó M√°s informaci√≥n

Agenda: SAP TechEd 2025 ‚Äì primeros anuncios SAP adelant√≥ que la pr√≥xima edici√≥n de TechEd pondr√° foco en IA generativa, clean core y anal√≠tica en tiempo real. M√°s all√° de los keynotes, lo interesante es ver c√≥mo los anuncios aterrizan en roadmaps concretos. CIOs esperan claridad de inversi√≥n, consultores buscan nuevas certificaciones y arquitectos quieren entender las integraciones que vienen.

¬øQu√© esper√°s con m√°s inter√©s: casos pr√°cticos de IA, roadmap de S/4HANA o nuevas certificaciones de BTP?

üîó M√°s informaci√≥n

SAP BTP ofrece un valor √∫nico seg√∫n el rol que lo mire. Para el CIO significa eficiencia, para el CFO transparencia y control financiero, para el arquitecto la posibilidad de dise√±ar integraciones m√°s simples, para el Basis la tranquilidad de la estabilidad operativa y para el consultor la oportunidad de acelerar la entrega de valor. Sin embargo, m√°s all√° de esas perspectivas, todos enfrentamos la misma tensi√≥n: c√≥mo lograr que la innovaci√≥n se convierta en resultados tangibles sin perder el control en el proceso.

entry.title: AI Assisted Data Quality Screening in SAP Business Data Cloud
entry.content:
Ensuring Data Excellence in Mixed-Source Environments Through AI & Automated Frameworks

Introduction

Organizations today rely on data from multiple sources to drive critical business decisions in their data platform. SAP Business Data Cloud  excels at integrating both SAP and non-SAP data into a unified platform. However maintaining consistent data quality across these diverse sources presents unique challenges, especially for the non-SAP data.

SAP Business Applications typically deliver high-quality data thanks to their robust semantically rich business logic and built-in validation rules applied at the point of extraction. However, non-SAP data sources often lack these same quality safeguards, creating potential inconsistencies that can compromise analytical outcomes.

Poor data quality isn't just a technical inconvenience - it's a business risk that directly impacts your organization's ability to compete & make accurate decisions and trust the data. That‚Äôs why it should be top of mind in a data platform design to have a continuous solution.

 

What did we do?

SAP Datasphere  includes native data integrity checks, these require manual execution. But our purpose was to build something that could screen an entire environment daily & report back on the data quality inconsistencies. And we wanted it to have as little manual work to setup so we built it from the top up with AI in mind to assist

To bridge this gap, my colleagues and I have developed an advanced AI assisted Data Quality Framework (DQF) specifically engineered for SAP Datasphere environments. This framework transforms data quality management from a reactive, manual process into a proactive, automated system that continuously monitors, evaluates, and reports on data integrity across all sources.

It transforms data quality management from a time-consuming manual process into an automated system that works at the speed of your business, ensuring that every piece of data in your SAP Datasphere environment - regardless of its origin - meets the same rigorous standards you expect from native SAP business applications even when the data is not coming from SAP.

In this blog, we'll examine the key features, how this framework was built, its core capabilities, and how to use it and what results it brings. The goal is to showcase the near limitless possibilities within SAP Business Data Cloud as a modern data environment.

 

  • Key Features and Benefits

The Data Quality Framework (DQF) is meticulously designed to ensure the integrity and accuracy of data within SAP Datasphere, especially of non-SAP data & manual data like excel, csv, etc. The framework performs a series of critical checks, including the identification of NULL values in key fields, referential integrity checks with master data, and duplicate records detection. These checks provide accurate record-level details necessary for data validation, cleansing, governance, and monitoring and reporting.

At the end the results of the checks are posted to a report which can be used by IT or business to fix the data quality & integrity issues in the files or systems.

 

  • Use Cases and Prerequisites

The Data Quality Framework is versatile and can validate data from various sources, including non-SAP sources like Databases, CSV files, excel files, etc. It can also be used to do checks on data created within  SAP Datasphere after using joins.

The setup requires access to the SAP HANA Cloud Database in SAP Datasphere & setup of a user, couple of tables & Stored procedures in that HANA Layer. Additionally, any views the stored procedure needs to screen should be exposed for consumption.

 

  • Architecture

The architecture of our DQF is designed to handle screenings efficiently & automatically and showcase the errors to end users to take action on the Data Quality itself.

The process begins with the main procedure: the ETL_RunScreenings. This script starts the process with a couple of parameters to allow customisability: Only check object x, only check objects in space y, only execute check 1.

The orchestra master if you will is a list called Screenings. This is an AI generated table that consists all of the screening rules per data object in your data platform. See an example below. We gave an agent the structure of the table, the functional blueprint of the DQF, code & ERD schema‚Äôs of our Data Warehouse Billing Model. The question was then asked: Populate this table to the best of your ability. The result:

Following this, the Framework then branches into three critical checks: ETL_SCREEN_REFERENTIAL_INTEGRITY, ETL_SCREEN_DUPLICATE, and ETL_SCREEN_NULLKEYS. Each of these checks points to respective error tables, ensuring that any discrepancies are promptly identified and addressed. The framework allows for multiple ETL Screening but currently there are 3:

  • Referential Integrity check: Checks if the key value in a fact finds a key value in the dimension. This ensures an association will retrieve master data.
  • Duplicate Check: Checks if a duplicate exists on a certain key
  • Null Keys/mal keys Check: Checks if one of the fields that is set as key has null values

 

  • Implementation Steps

Implementing the DQF involves several key steps:

  1. Create a database user in the Datasphere tenant. (Use Space Management)
  2. Create tables and stored procedures in the open SQL schema of the created database user. (Code will shared later once quality reviewed ‚Äì we used DBeaver for this)
  3. Grant access to the Datasphere space for the task chain to access the stored procedures.
  4. Create task chains to schedule the stored procedure runs.
  5. Feed an AI Agent or LLM of choice with the code, table layout of SCREENING & ERD schema of your model and ask to fill in the rules. Do a visual check afterward & manually adjust where needed.
  6. Create a view to combine the screening tables.
  7. Report errors using a report built in SAP Analytics Cloud 

 

  • End Result

To illustrate the practical application of the DQF, let‚Äôs look at example diagram of the data flow in a DSP system. The diagram highlights the flow of data from source entities through transformations and unions, leading to storage and further processing. Key elements include entities, dimensions, facts, attributes, and a screening framework, with specific keys and NULL replacements noted.

The result is an error page on which you can build a report. See example below where it shows what constraint was violated in what screening run & what the values were that caused the error. See for example line 7 where a duplicate key was found & then it shows the exact key that created the duplicate.

A business or IT user can then take matters into control & fix the data at source based on this report. Or coordinate if action/logic needs to be developed in the Data Platform to catch this.

 

Conclusion

In conclusion: the Data Quality Framework we created is an AI-driven automated solution to enhance data integrity and accuracy within SAP Datasphere & SAP Business Data Cloud on a constant basis. It builds on top of the already powerful manual integrity checks. But the framework expands by offering a daily, automated & AI assisted approach. By implementing these kind of checks consistently, organizations can ensure that their data is reliable, consistent, and ready for informed decision-making.

What‚Äôs next? We are looking to expand to do data type check. We are now also running full validation on the script & doing some code quality & clean-up. Once this is done, we can share the script. Feel free to contact me at simon.vandelanotte@delaware.pro if you want a sneak peak.

Because fun fact: The script was partly written thanks to assistance from AI. As neither Premalatha or myself are SQLscript coders from background, this was our first experience!

I hope this case already inspires on the endless possibilities with SAP Business Data Cloud& inspire around the important topic of Data Quality and how proactively being on top of this is critical to the success of a modern data platform. And lastly how AI doesn‚Äôt replace the process but can enhance it & save time.

Big thanks to my colleague Premalatha Kamaraj for writing this script & Gilles De Rore for the idea!

entry.title: How to add BW Last Data Update field to SAP Analytics Cloud + Datasphere (SAP Note 2706430)
entry.content:
Summary

SAP Note 2706430 - How to get latest datasource update/refresh data date/time in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)?
Improvement Request 219791 - Dynamic text for datasource last refresh date and time

When customers move from SAP BW to SAP Datasphere + SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC), a common ask is: ‚ÄúWhere‚Äôs the BW-style Last Data Update field?‚Äù SAC‚Äôs dynamic-text / model metadata doesn‚Äôt reliably supply a full source refresh timestamp for all scenarios, so the recommended pattern is to capture the refresh timestamp at the source (or during the import/persistence flow), expose it through a small tracking table / SQL view and then surface it in the SAC story via dynamic text on a small analytic model. This post shows a practical, production-ready approach and pitfalls to watch out for.

 

Introduction

Customers migrating from SAP Business Warehouse (BW) often miss the metadata field ‚ÄúLast Data Update‚Äù that shows when a dataset was last refreshed. BW had the table RSDINFOPROVDATA to store that info for each BW data cube‚Äî in Datasphere/HANA + SAC we can recreate this pattern. This post explains a reproducible approach:

  1. discover the underlying tables/views for your Analytical Model (lineage),
  2. create a small refresh-tracking table,
  3. populate it during your delta-import, import or persistence flows
  4. combine tracked records using a SQL View, and
  5. expose it to SAC using a tiny analytic model
  6. consume the information using a dynamic text filed in your story

 

1) Find the source objects 

Use Datasphere / HANA lineage features (calculation view lineage) or the HANA system view OBJECT_DEPENDENCIES to find which base tables feed your Analytical Model / calculation view. Example SQL to use in HANA Database Explore:

SELECT TOP 1000000
  "BASE_DATABASE_SCHEMA_NAME",
  "BASE_DATABASE_NAME",
  "BASE_SCHEMA_NAME",
  "BASE_OBJECT_NAME",
  "BASE_OBJECT_TYPE",
  "DEPENDENT_DATABASE_NAME",
  "DEPENDENT_SCHEMA_NAME",
  "DEPENDENT_OBJECT_NAME",
  "DEPENDENT_OBJECT_TYPE",
  "DEPENDENCY_TYPE"
FROM "PUBLIC"."OBJECT_DEPENDENCIES"
WHERE "DEPENDENT_SCHEMA_NAME" = '<SPACE_NAME>'
  AND "DEPENDENT_OBJECT_NAME" LIKE '<Analytical_Model_Name>%'
  AND "BASE_OBJECT_TYPE" = 'TABLE';

This gives you the base tables that the model depends on. if you have multiple analyitc models it is a best practise to group these where possible.

 

2) Create a tracking table (‚ÄúRSDINFOPROVDATA‚Äù equivalent)

Create a small table to capture last refresh timestamps for each tracked table. I recommend to enable it for Delta capture.

When Importing data across different spaces you need to create multiple tables since shared tables are read only. These tables can later be joined in step 4.

 

3) Populate the tracking table during data import/ persistence

Pattern A ‚Äî Import using delta tables

If you have delta tables (e.g., <TABLE>_Delta), use a transformation flow to compute the latest timestamp and upsert it into 1TL_Last_Delta.

Example SQL used by a transformation flow:

SELECT t."View_Name", t."Last_Refresh" FROM "<DELTA TABLE>" t 
WHERE "View_Name" IN ('<TRACKED TABLE 1>', '<TRACKED TABLE 2>', '<TRACKED TABLE 3>', '<TRACKED TABLE 4>') 
UNION ALL 
SELECT 'MAX_<TRACKED TABLE 1>_<TRACKED TABLE 2>' AS "View_Name", MAX(t."Last_Refresh") AS "Last_Refresh" FROM "<DELTA TABLE>" t 
WHERE t."View_Name" IN ( '<TRACKED TABLE 1>', '<TRACKED TABLE 2>' )

Schedule this transformation flow according to how fresh you need the timestamp. A typical balance is hourly ‚Äî fine-grained enough for most BI needs but light on compute. (If you need real-time, use the import chains that run on every update; see Pattern B below.)

Pattern B ‚Äî Import using a task chain and table persistence

If you use a task chain to import or persist tables, attach a final transformation step that writes the current timestamp / last-change value to 1TL_Last_Delta. For persisted tables you can also read the ‚Äú<TABLE>_Delta‚Äù tables using a transformation flow to determine last modification time. Careful this may lead to false information incase you persist your data without checking if new data is available.

 

4) Combine tracked data into a single SQL view your model can consume

You may have to join or union several tables or tracked objects (for a model that depends on multiple tables). Example view:

SELECT
  t."VIEW_NAME",
  t."LAST_REFRESH"
FROM "<SPACE_NAME>"."TRACK_REFRESH" t
WHERE t."VIEW_NAME" IN ('<TRACKED_TABLE_1>', '<TRACKED_TABLE_2>', '<TRACKED_TABLE_3>')
UNION ALL
-- optional: an aggregated row (MAX of two tracked tables)
SELECT
  'MAX_<TRACKED_TABLE_1>_<TRACKED_TABLE_2>' AS "VIEW_NAME",
  MAX(t."LAST_REFRESH") AS "LAST_REFRESH"
FROM "<SPACE_NAME>"."TRACK_REFRESH" t
WHERE t."VIEW_NAME" IN ('<TRACKED_TABLE_1>', '<TRACKED_TABLE_2>')

 

 

5) Expose to SAP Analytics Cloud

Option A ‚Äî Single analytic model with a View_Name variable (recommended)

  • Create a Datasphere Analytic Model that exposes the view created in step 4 and add a filter variable View_Name.
  • In the SAC story, set the variable to the name of the table your story is dependent on. Then add dynamic text that references the Last_Refresh value.

Pros: fewer models to maintain, single point of truth.
Cons: depends on how well story variables persist and on your story variable settings for bookmarks; if your story must clear variables on load, you may use the pattern below.

Option B ‚Äî One analytic model per story / analytic model

If you cannot rely on story-level variables (for example if your stories use ‚ÄúClear Variables and Use Server-Defined Values‚Äù or bookmarks that clear variables), create a small analytic model per story or analytic model that already filters to the ‚ÄúVIEW_NAME‚Äù-value that story needs.

Pros: deterministic for each story/leading table and avoids variable state issues or user from changing the variable.
Cons: model overhead with poor maintainability.

Option C ‚Äî Integration in existing analytic model

If you cannot rely on story-level variables (for example if your stories use ‚ÄúClear Variables and Use Server-Defined Values‚Äù or bookmarks that clear variables), you can also integrate the timestamps in the existing analytical model. this may be more difficult in complex analytic models and produces excess data and is poor to maintain!

 

6) Display in SAC story

Once the LAST_REFRESH is available as a dimension in your SAC Story you can add a text box to the story and Insert ‚Üí Dynamic Text ‚Üí Dimension ‚Üí choose <ANALYICAL_MODEL> ‚Üí choose ‚ÄúLast Refresh‚Äù. Also make sure to configure the filter accordingly to step 5.

I recommend using "Last Updated" for Pattern A and "Data Current as of" for Pattern B from step 3.

 

References

  • Add Dynamic Text to a Story  SAP Help Portal
  • Set Story Variables SAP Help Portal
  • OBJECT_DEPENDENCIES System View (HANA Cloud SQL reference) SAP Help Portal
  • Community thread discussing ‚Äúget latest datasource update/refresh‚Äù SAP Community
  • SAP Note 2706430 - How to get latest datasource update/refresh data date/time in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)
  • Improvement Request 219791 - Dynamic text for datasource last refresh date and time

entry.title: Session 1 Recap & Highlight - SAP BDC The Future of Intelligent Data Architectures üöÄ
entry.content:
Why SAP Invested in BDC üí°

The journey started with SAP‚Äôs recognition of a growing "context gap" in enterprise data‚Äîwhich emerges when organizations must stitch together SAP and non-SAP data across disparate platforms (think Databricks, Snowflake, Microsoft Fabric). Without business context, analytics and AI initiatives often struggle to deliver real value. BDC was built to close this gap by harmonizing and managing all enterprise data‚Äîstructured, semi-structured, SAP, and non-SAP‚Äîin a unified, semantically enriched way.

 

What Sets BDC Apart? üéØ

  • Automation First: BDC flips the script on traditional data management, automating data curation and harmonization. Instead of endless upfront effort, customers get ready-to-consume, semantically rich data products‚Äîsaving time and reducing what SAP calls the ‚Äúhidden data tax‚Äù.
  • Data Product Model: SAP identifies ‚Äúprimary data products‚Äù (like finance, supply chain, HR) and brings them directly from SAP applications into BDC, curated and cataloged for instant use. The goal is to reach 500 data products by year-end‚Äîcovering virtually every major enterprise domain.
  • AI-Ready Fabric: BDC‚Äôs lakehouse architecture and built-in ‚Äúbusiness fabric‚Äù layer empower businesses to use advanced analytics, natural language queries, and AI seamlessly. Dual integration and knowledge graph support mean both applications and users can access harmonized, context-rich insights.

 

Interoperability & Ecosystem üåê

  • BDC Connect: This technology helps integrate BDC with non-SAP systems like Databricks, enabling zero-copy data sharing and harmonized catalogs‚Äîperfect for hybrid and multicloud enterprises.
  • Marketplace Vision: SAP is launching a data products marketplace, encouraging partners and customers to publish, consume, and innovate with SAP and non-SAP data. The upcoming announcement at SAP Connect will explain how the ecosystem and intelligent apps can grow‚Äîmost delivered by partners, not just SAP.

 

Data Democratization: Empowering Every Employee üë•

Pinar described SAP‚Äôs internal rollout‚Äî‚Äúcustomer zero‚Äù‚Äîwhere business users, not just IT, access BDC‚Äôs data products and build dashboards in hours. This isn‚Äôt just technology; SAP orchestrates enablement cohorts, training citizen analysts to maximize value and foster data-driven decision making at every level.

  • Reusable Data Products: Designed for broad, multi-use case consumption, not one-off analytics. Both IT and business users (citizen analysts) can build, extend, and share data-driven solutions thanks to low-code/no-code tooling.
  • Enablement & Governance: SAP couples technology with strong governance and enablement programs‚Äîusing Collibra for cataloging, trust-building, and making metadata as easy to navigate as grocery shopping.

 

 

üåçWhether you‚Äôre an enterprise architect, citizen analyst, or just curious about the future of business intelligence‚ÄîSAP Business Data Cloud delivers a new foundation for turning data into real business outcomes, faster and smarter than ever before.

üôã‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è Which BDC feature excites you most? Are you ready for data democratization in your organization? Share your thoughts below!

Note: Slides from the session and the recording would be only available to the registered attendees. So if you have not registered, please register now using the link below:

https://events.sap.com/eaa-bdc-apac/en_us/home.html#accordion-5d79451476-item-9ff3b2b36e

 

Important links üîó

  1. Architecture Center: https://architecture.learning.sap.com/
  2. Enterprise Architect Learning Journey: https://learning.sap.com/learning-journeys/discovering-sap-enterprise-architecture
  3. SAP Business Data Cloud Learning Journey: https://learning.sap.com/courses/introducing-sap-business-data-cloud

@IrfanKhan  @Gaurish-Dessai  @ralph_richter

entry.title: Using Technical User in SAP Datasphere Consumption APIs (Client Credentials)
entry.content:
SAP Datasphere exposes business-ready data through a set of Consumption APIs that make it easy for BI tools and applications to query governed data without copying it. The Consumption APIs endpoints generated from Analytical Datasets and Analytic Models offer a metadata-rich, RESTful interface that applications can call for filtered, paged results, which have been available since early 2021. 

To allow all this richness of data and the benefits of federation capabilities, the SAP Dataspshere Consumption APIs always relied on business users for authentication and authorizations, which is based OAuth 2.0 with Authorization Code grant type. Such scenario ensured the same behaviour the user sees in the SAP Datasphere or SAP Analytics applications would be the one be the same when integrating via APIs, including Data Access Controls and Model Privileges.

However such authorization method is not the most adequate to be used when integration in backend application, in a service-to-service manner. As in most cases the backend application does not have an current user session or ability to access a browser context as required by Authorization Code grant type 3-lagged approach.

With that we heard our users requests and pleased to release the "Technical User" support for the SAP Datasphere Consumption APIs which is based on OAuth 2.0 with Client Credentials grant type (2-legged). This allows the access token generation to happen without any manual user interaction.

This blog post cover details on how to create the "Technical User" OAuth Client in SAP Datasphere, how to setup the client credentiral authorization in Postman and the support for it on Power BI Custom Connector.

Technical User OAuth Client

The Technical User OAuth client work just like the other OAuth clients existing in SAP Datasphere. To define the authorizations for the technical user at least one scoped role needs to be assigned to it, this will determine which spaces the technical user will have access and the privileges it will have in them.  Also, to identify the requests made and to apply data access restrictions a "Username" must be provided, this technical user name needs to be unique across the entire SAP Datasphere tenant.

For creating a Technical User OAuth client, go to System > Administration > App Integration and provide the following information

  • Purpose: Technical User
  • User ID:  <unique username>
  • Roles: <Select at least one scoped role>

After creating it generates a "Client ID" and a "Client Secret", just like the other OAuth client types.

 

Integrating with Consumption APIs in Postman

Integrating with SAP Datasphere Consumption APIs using a Technical User OAuth client is straightforward because it uses the Client Credentials grant type. Using the client_id and client_secret created in the previous section, along with the SAP Datasphere token URL available on the App Integration page, you can use any HTTP client (e.g., Postman) to generate an access token and call the Consumption APIs.

Access Token Generation

Postman Automated OAuth Setup

Postman‚Äôs automated authorization handles all the necessary OAuth 2.0 calls to retrieve and apply the token. To set this up, create a new request and open the Authorization tab. For Type, select OAuth 2.0 and fill in the following information:

  • Header Prefix: Bearer
  • Grant type: Client Credentials
  • Access Token URL: <SAP Datasphere Token URL available the App Integration page>
  • Client ID: <client_id - created on previous step>
  • Client Secret: <client_secret - created on previous step>

After you complete the fields, click Get New Access Token. Postman will generate an access token for SAP Datasphere.

Postman Manual OAuth Setup

Postman‚Äôs approach in the previous section automates the OAuth protocol, which is helpful for testing and speeding up debugging, but less practical for real integrations. This section explains how to craft the OAuth token request required by the Client Credentials flow for use with a SAP Datasphere Technical User.

Create a request in Postman and configure:

  • Method: POST
  • Request URL: <token_url> (the SAP Datasphere token URL available on the App Integration page)

Headers:

  • Authorization: Basic <base64 encoded client_id:client_secret>
  • Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded

Body (x-www-form-urlencoded):

  • grant_type: client_credentials

Send the request to retrieve the access token, which you will use later.

 

Changes on SAP Datasphere Consumption APIs

The SAP Datasphere Consumption APIs let you retrieve data via OData version 4. Starting with release 2025.19, the standard API path has been updated to align with proper service naming following the 2023 transition from SAP Data Warehouse Cloud to SAP Datasphere and its continued role within the SAP Business Data Cloud strategy.

  • New path: /api/v1/datasphere/consumption/*

The catalog service for consumption artifacts, which lists and queries all accessible spaces and entities, has moved to /api/v1/datasphere/consumption/catalog/* to better reflect its purpose. All other semantics for accessing spaces and assets remain unchanged.

The relational and analytical consumption endpoints retain exactly the same behavior, with only the path prefix changed, for example:

  • /api/v1/datasphere/consumption/(relational | analytical)/*

The previous path, /api/v1/dwc/(catalog|consumption), is deprecated. It will continue to be supported for 18 months, until March 2027.

Consuming with Technical User

You can use the Technical User with both the old and new API paths. Once you switch to Technical User authorization, it is recommended to move to the new standard endpoints.

When you make requests to the Consumption APIs with Technical User authorization, the privileges and space memberships applied to the request are determined by the scoped roles assigned to the OAuth client used to generate the access token.

For example, consider spaces A, B, and C. If the OAuth client has roles that grant consumption permissions for spaces A and C, then:

  • In catalog queries, only assets from spaces A and C are returned.
  • For data consumption, only models belonging to or shared with spaces A and C are accessible.

An example request is shown in the image below, which requests data from a view in relational format, use the generated access token from previous step as Bearer Authorization.

Important notice: Consuming data from assets protected by Data Access Controls is not supported at this time. The API will return an empty result.

 

Integration with Power BI via Custom Connector

Back in 2022, olaf_fischer and I worked on easing the integration between Power BI and the SAP Datasphere Consumption APIs by releasing an open source sample Power BI Custom Connector that supports SSO, making it easy to authenticate and consume the OData APIs in Power BI.

Although the custom connector has its limitations and active development has ceased, the introduction of a new authorization type is a significant improvement. Since the connector is used by many, it deserved an update to align with the latest features. I am happy to share that version 1.90 of the open source custom connector now supports authorization via OAuth 2.0 with client credentials.

More details on the custom connector can be found at original blog post or on the GitHub Repository

How to Use It in Power BI

  1. In the connector sign-in dialog, choose Authentication Method ‚Üí ‚ÄúOAuth Client Credentials.‚Äù
  2. Enter the Client ID and Client Secret generated when you registered the app.
  3. Leave the existing Access Token URL in the system settings (connections.json file); no additional user details are required.

Backward-Compatibility Notes

  • Existing connections that use the Authorization Code flow continue to work unchanged.
  • You can reuse the same system configuration (Access Token URL) if you switch to the new Client Credentials flow later.
 

Summary

SAP Datasphere now supports Technical User access to the Consumption APIs with OAuth 2.0 client credentials, enabling service-to-service integrations without user interaction and thereby easing integration across multiple services and enabling many new use cases.

I‚Äôd be happy to hear your thoughts and comments on this topic. Let me know in the comments

entry.title: Unlocking a Cleaner and Greener Energy Future with AI
entry.content:
The United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) mandate rapid clean energy adoption to combat climate change. However, many utilities still face hurdles integrating renewables such as solar, wind, and hydropower into increasingly intelligent, distributed grids. Digital transformation, powered by AI, can enable accurate forecasting, predictive analytics, and IoT-driven self-healing grids, unlocking a sustainable future at scale.

Gartner projects that by 2027, over 50% of enterprise AI models will be industry-specific, up from about 1% in 2023. For utilities, this shift toward domain-tuned AI accelerates adoption in forecasting, asset performance, and customer operations. IDC‚Äôs Utilities predictions and Forrester‚Äôs Generative AI outlook similarly point to a pivot from pilot to production, with measured value in core operational use cases

AI Use Cases and SAP Utilities Solutions:

  • Advanced Renewable Forecasting: AI brings together historical generation, weather, and grid conditions to predict renewable output, enhance grid stability, and optimize dispatch. SAP enablers: SAP Energy Data Management (EDM), SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC), SAP Datasphere for data fabric, and SAP S/4HANA Utilities for integration.
  • Intelligent Demand-Side Management: AI dynamically adjusts loads across sectors - smart appliances, EVs, industrial processes balancing supply and reducing peaks. SAP enablers: SAP Cloud for Utilities, SAP BRIM and SAP Subscription Billing for innovative tariffs, and SAC for optimization.
  • Proactive Predictive Maintenance: AI-driven anomaly detection improves asset reliability and avoids costly outages. SAP enablers: SAP Asset Performance Management (APM), SAP Asset Intelligence Network (AIN), SAP Field Service Management (FSM), and SAP S/4HANA Asset Management.

What are the opportunities of converging AI and SAP Solutions?

  • Reliability & Predictive Maintenance at Scale
    AI models fuse SCADA, asset history, and condition data to detect anomalies early, optimize spares, and move from time-based to condition-based maintenance - cutting SAIDI/SAIFI and truck rolls.

SAP enablers: SAP Asset Performance Management (APM), SAP Field Service Management (FSM), SAP S/4HANA Asset Management, SAP Asset Intelligence Network (AIN), and SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) for predictive insights.

  • DER Orchestration, Flexibility & Market Settlement
    Forecasting and dispatching behind-the-meter solar, storage, EVs, and microgrids; forming virtual power plants (VPPs)  and optimizing participation in flexibility/ancillary markets.

SAP enablers: SAP Energy Data Management (EDM) for metering and settlement, SAP Billing and Revenue Innovation Management (BRIM) and SAP Subscription Billing for new tariffs and flexibility services, SAP S/4HANA Utilities for end-to-end customer-to-cash, and SAP Analytics Cloud for forecast optimization.

  • Customer & Prosumer Experience (CX) and Personalized Energy Services
    Hyper-personalized advisory, usage insights, TOU nudges, EV-smart-charging offers, and prosumer engagement that drive satisfaction and reduce churn.

SAP enablers: SAP S/4HANA Utilities, SAP BRIM for complex pricing/bundles, SAP Subscription Billing, SAP Customer Data Platform (CDP), SAP Service Cloud, and SAP Marketing Cloud for tailored engagement.

  • Sustainability, Emissions & ‚ÄúGreen AI‚Äù Operations
    AI to optimize dispatch, reduce losses, and cut emissions; automated Scope 1‚Äì3 tracking and audit-ready reporting; and energy-efficient AI practices to minimize compute footprints.

SAP enablers: SAP Sustainability Control Tower (SCT) for KPI governance, SAP Product Footprint Management (PFM) for footprint calculations, SAP Environment, Health, and Safety (EHS) for operational compliance, and SAP Signavio for process redesign.

  • Workforce Productivity, Safety & Knowledge Capture
    AI copilots for planners/dispatchers; mobile assistants for field technicians (procedures, PPE checks, hazards); automated close-outs and claims; and computer vision for safety observance.

SAP enablers: SAP Field Service Management (FSM) (mobile work), SAP Asset Performance Management (APM) (procedures & failure modes), SAP EHS (permits/safety), SAP Build Work Zone and SAP Enable Now for just-in-time guidance.

  • Revenue Innovation & Margin Protection
    AI-informed margin management (hedging, loss reduction), prosumer/VPP monetization, dynamic pricing, flexibility services, and performance-based programs.

SAP enablers: SAP BRIM, SAP Subscription Billing, SAP Profitability and Performance Management (PaPM), SAP Analytics Cloud, and SAP Datasphere (data fabric for scenario modeling).

Let's look at the challenges and practical mitigations

  • Data Foundations, Quality & Interoperability: Model performance hinges on clean, timely, connected data across OT (SCADA, AMI, APM) and IT (billing, CRM).

Mitigations with SAP: Establish a utility data fabric with SAP Datasphere; unify meter/market data via SAP EDM; standardize models in SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP); use SAP Integration Suite for OT/IT connectors; govern with SAP Master Data Governance (MDG).

  • AI Risk, Governance & Model Compliance (AI TRiSM/Responsible AI): Bias, drift, explainability, safety, and regulatory scrutiny (especially for GenAI and automated decisioning).

Mitigations with SAP: Use SAP BTP with SAP AI Core and AI Launchpad for lifecycle control; log lineage and approvals; embed human-in-the-loop; instrument KPIs in SAC; codify policies in Signavio.

  • Cybersecurity & Critical Infrastructure Protection: Expanded attack surface across DERs, edge devices, mobile crews, and market interfaces; GenAI introduces new vectors (prompt injection, data leakage).

Mitigations with SAP: Apply least-privilege and policy-based access on SAP BTP; integrate security analytics; segment OT/IT interfaces; harden APIs with SAP Integration Suite; capture end-to-end audit trails.

  • Compute, Energy Footprint & ‚ÄúGreen AI‚Äù: Training/serving advanced models can inflate energy use, potentially conflicting with utility decarbonization goals.

Mitigations with SAP: Favor smaller, domain-tuned models hosted efficiently on SAP BTP; leverage inference optimization, demand-response scheduling of batch jobs, and carbon-aware routing; track emissions in SAP Sustainability Control Tower and Product Footprint Management.

  • Talent, Change & Operating Model: AI value stalls without product-centric teams, MLOps, and business ownership of outcomes.

Mitigations with SAP: Establish an AI value office; use SAP Signavio for process redesign; adopt MLOps on BTP/AI Launchpad; embed copilot-assisted work in SAP FSM and SAP S/4HANA.

  • Regulatory, Market & Ethical Constraints: Rate design, model explainability, and consumer data use are under tightening scrutiny.

Mitigations with SAP: Keep explainability artifacts for decisions (SAC narratives, model cards in AI Launchpad); enforce privacy-by-design with SAP CDP and consent management; maintain audit trails across EDM/BRIM/market processes.

Conclusion: 

AI is the cornerstone for clean energy transformation. By leveraging SAP‚Äôs intelligent utilities solutions and TCS‚Äôs innovation, utilities can boost efficiency, integrate renewables, and drive decarbonization. The path to a greener future lies in combining advanced technology with strategic energy management and robust governance. For CXOs, this means making informed, data-driven decisions, ensuring regulatory compliance, and creating sustainable value for customers and shareholders alike. Those who act decisively today will not only navigate the energy transition successfully but also set the benchmark for resilient, future-ready utilities.

entry.title: Build a Data-Driven Enterprise with SAP‚Äôs Data & Analytics Advisory Methodology
entry.content:
What is SAP BTP Guidance Framework: The Guidance Framework provides clear direction and a structured approach to adopting SAP technologies. With this guidance, you can develop intelligent applications using advanced analytics, equipping your organization with a robust foundation to support agile innovation. For more details read this blog. 

In this blog post, we will look into how to build a Data-Driven Enterprise with SAP‚Äôs Data & Analytics Advisory Methodology under SAP BTP Guidance Framework. You can find this Data & Analytics Advisory Methodology pillar under SAP BTP Guidance Framework. 

It‚Äôs imperative that in today‚Äôs economy, data is more than just numbers‚Äîit‚Äôs the foundation of innovation, strategy, and growth backed by AI. Yet many organizations still struggle to unlock the full potential of their data and give it purpose. SAP‚Äôs Data & Analytics Advisory Methodology under SAP BTP Guidance Framework offers a structured, four-phase approach that helps enterprises transform raw data into actionable insights while building a strong data-driven culture. 

The Four Phases of SAP‚Äôs Data & Analytics Advisory Methodology 

1. Scoping & Baseline Analysis: In this phase you can set the foundation by: 

  • Defining the scope of investigation across business processes, organizational units, and data domains. 
  • Assessing current data architecture and capabilities. 
  • Identifying gaps, pain points, and opportunities for improvement. 

Benefit of this phase is that your business will have a clear baseline architecture, capability assessment, and prioritized opportunities. 

2. Business Outcomes & Solution Requirements: the focus in this phase shifts to aligning data with measurable business goals such as:  

  • Define specific, data-driven business outcomes. 
  • Analyze use cases that trace how raw data transforms into business value. 
  • Identify required data products and map end-to-end integration flows. 

This phase allows to clearly define business outcome definitions and solution context diagrams. 

 3. Capability Map & Solution Architecture: this phase transforms requirements into a target architecture by: 

  • Developing a capability map using SAP BTP Maturity Assessment 
  • Explore architecture options through traditional capability mapping or solution diagrams from the SAP Discovery Center. 
  • Validate the preferred architecture with proof-of-concepts. 

With this phase the target solution architecture is validated through capability mapping and pilots. 

 4. Data Governance & Roadmaps: this final phase ensures long-term sustainability: 

  • Conduct a maturity assessment for data governance and organizational roles. 
  • Define roles such as Chief Data Officer, Data Steward, and Governance Manager. 
  • Build a roadmap with clear clusters (e.g., implementation, operations, security). 

The key benefit of this phase is to define Data governance framework, organizational structure, and a roadmap for execution. 

What makes SAP‚Äôs Data & Analytics Advisory Methodology stand out is that it‚Äôs not just about technology‚Äîit‚Äôs about data, people and processes. By integrating governance, roles, and organizational change management, it ensures that data initiatives aren‚Äôt just implemented but also adopted across the enterprise. For organizations aiming to thrive in a data-driven economy, SAP‚Äôs Data & Analytics Advisory Methodology provides more than a roadmap‚Äîit delivers a proven framework for turning data into business value and give it purpose. By combining architecture best practices with governance and cultural adoption, it helps enterprises evolve from simply managing data to truly innovating with it. 

To read more about SAP‚Äôs Data & Analytics Advisory Methodology check out SAP Discovery Center. 

‚ÄúOrganizations that adopt this framework position themselves to lead in the AI-driven economy‚Äù 

Previous blogs in the series:

  • SAP BTP AI Best Practices: Your Ultimate Guide for Building AI Solutions
  • SAP Discovery Center Expands and Welcomes the SAP BTP Guidance Framework
  • SAP BTP Developer‚Äôs Guide: Essential Best Practices from Setup to Scale
  • Introducing SAP Application Extension Methodology version 2.4

Stay tuned for the next blog post in our ‚ÄòExploring the SAP BTP Guidance Framework‚Äô series!
